document.title: debin - A declarative binary parser for Python
document.description: debin is a fast, declarative binary parser for Python. Define binary formats using dataclasses and get type-safe, Rust-powered parsing with zero boilerplate.

body.raw:
If you work with binary data, you know how painful parsing can be. Reverse engineering file formats, decoding game assets, or inspecting packets usually means manual offsets, brittle slicing, and unreadable code.

I wanted something better. So I built debin.

# What Is Binary Parsing?

Binary parsing converts raw bytes into structured data. Instead of a wall of hex, you define fields and structure such as headers, payloads, and conditional sections.

Binary data is everywhere, but parsing it in Python is often unpleasant.



So how do we do this simply using an easy-to-use language like Python? 


# A Tour of Existing Tools (This isn't new)

Before creating debin, I tried a few existing ibraries:

- [struct](https://docs.python.org/3/library/struct.html) - Pythonâ€™s built-in option. Fast and native, but primitive. You're on your own for everything beyond the basics.
- [bitstring](https://github.com/scott-griffiths/bitstring) -  Useful for parsing at the bit level, but too low-level and verbose for structured formats. A lot similar to struct.
- [construct](https://construct.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) - A powerful declarative and symmetrical parser and builder for binary data.
- [caterpillar](https://matrixeditor.github.io/caterpillar/) - Loved the creativity, but it leans into a DSL-like syntax. It's clever, but doesnâ€™t feel like Python anymore.


## My Design Choice

debin keeps everything native to Python. You use dataclasses, type hints, and decorators. No DSL, no format strings, and no manual offsets.

It was heavily inspired by [binrw](https://docs.rs/binrw/latest/binrw/index.html), a Rust declarative binary parser. [binrw](https://docs.rs/binrw/latest/binrw/index.html) is fast and elegant, but Rust has a steep learning curve. debin brings that model to Python while keeping performance high using Rust internally.


# Introducing debin ðŸ§™
debin lets you define binary formats using simple dataclasses. It generates fast, type safe parsers automatically.

Typical parsing with [struct](https://docs.python.org/3/library/struct.html):

```python
import struct

data = open("object.bin", "rb").read()

x, y, z, object_id = struct.unpack("<fffI", data)

obj = {
    "position": {"x": x, "y": y, "z": z},
    "id": object_id
}
```

The problems:

- Format strings are fragile

- No structure or type safety

- Hard to scale or reuse


The same example in debin:

```python
from debin import *


@debin
class Vec3:
    x: float32
    y: float32
    z: float32

@debin
class Object:
    position: Vec3
    id: uint32

with open("sample.bin", "rb") as file:
        buffer = file.read()
obj = Object.read_le(buffer)
```
No offsets or unpacking. Just describe the format.

# It Gets Even Better


debin also supports:

- Conditional fields

- Variable length lists

- Dynamic parsing logic

- Nested structures


Example PNG parser:

```python

from debin import *
from debin.helpers import until_eof

@debin(magic=b"\x89PNG\r\n\x1a\n")
class PNGSignature:
    pass  # Magic-only section

@debin
class PNGChunk:
    length: uint32
    type: bytes4
    data: List[uint8] = field(metadata={"count": 'length'})
    crc: uint32

@debin
class PNGFile:
    signature: PNGSignature
    chunks: List[PNGChunk] = field(metadata={"parse_with": until_eof})
```
Define the structure and debin handles the parsing.

Want to learn more or try it for yourself? ðŸ§™

```bash
pip install debin
```

ðŸ’» Github: https://github.com/maxcabd/debin

ðŸ“¦ PyPi : https://pypi.org/project/debin/

Issues, feedback, and PRs are always welcome.

document.title: xfbin-rs
document.description: A Rust library for working with .xfbin files from the STORM and All Star Battle games by CyberConnect2.

body.raw:
# xfbin-rs

A Rust library for reading / writing .xfbin files from the STORM and All Star Battle games by CyberConnect2.
Python bindings are also [available](https://github.com/maxcabd/xfbin-rs-py) for this library

document.title: Introducing Blinked
document.description: Blinked lets you sell digital content with a link. No storefronts. No friction. Just create, share, and get paid.

body.raw:
The internet runs on links.

Links to videos. Links to files. Links to ideas. Links to value.

But one thing links have never been able to do well is get paid.

If you want to sell something digital today, you are forced into platforms that were not built for how people actually share content. You need storefronts, product pages, onboarding flows, and dashboards. You need to bring people somewhere else.

That breaks the natural flow of the internet.

People do not share storefronts. They share links.

So we built Blinked.

# What is Blinked

Blinked lets you sell digital content with a link.

Upload a file. Set a price. Share the link.

That is it.

No storefront. No setup. No friction.

The link becomes the product.

When someone opens it, they can instantly pay and access the content. Delivery is automatic. No manual fulfillment. No waiting.

It works anywhere links work. Messages. Social media. Email. Anywhere.

# Built for how people actually share

Creators today operate in conversations, not storefronts.

They sell in DMs. In group chats. On Instagram. On Threads. On Discord.

The infrastructure never adapted to that.

Blinked does not try to pull people into a platform. It works inside the flow that already exists.

Create once. Share anywhere.

# Digital value should move instantly

Digital content is instant by nature.

Payments and delivery should be too.

With Blinked, the moment someone pays, access is granted immediately. No delays. No manual steps. No complexity.

The entire transaction happens through a single link.

# Simple by design

We built Blinked around a simple idea.

Selling digital content should feel like sending a message.

Not running a store.

Not managing a platform.

Just creating something valuable and sharing it.
